# Phonomorphological anticipation

## Central Swedish

Low tone + singular: _fisken_ 'fish<sub>[SG]</sub>'     
High tone + plural: _fiskar_ 'fish<sub>[PL]</sub>' <font size="-1">     
(Roll et al., 2010)</font>

## Spanish
First syllable stressed + present: _canta_ 's/he sings'     
First syllable unstressed + preterite: _cantó_ 's/he sang' <font size="-1">     
(Sagarra & Casillas, 2018)</font>

???
Not learned in class so picked up through experience

</br>

# Lexical stress-suffix associations

- Spanish, English and Chinese have stress
  - Contrastive in Spanish and English; confounded with tones in Chinese
  
- Inflectional morphology in Spanish and English; particles and classifiers in Chinese
  - Spanish richer than English

# Our study

## Does L1 transfer affect English and Mandarin Chinese speakers' ability to make stress-tense suffix predictions in L2 Spanish? If so, how?

## Does L2 use affect English and Mandarin Chinese speakers' ability to make stress-tense suffix predictions in L2 Spanish? If so, how?

--
- English faster and more likely to predict than Chinese speakers because of similarity
- More use will contribute to faster and likelier prediction

---

# Our study

Participants:
- 30 Spanish monolinguals
- 65 English speakers (L2 Spanish intermediate or above)
- 64 Mandarin Chinese speakers (L2 Spanish intermediate or above)

Materials:
- Proficiency test
- Language history questionnaire
- Visual world paradigm (eye-tracking)
  
---

# Our study

Participants:
- 30 Spanish monolinguals
- 65 English speakers (L2 Spanish intermediate or above)
- 64 Mandarin Chinese speakers (L2 Spanish intermediate or above)

Materials:
- Proficiency test
- Language history questionnaire
- Visual world paradigm (eye-tracking)

Analysis:
- Growth Curve Analysis <font size="-1">(Mirman, 2014)</font>

```{r eval=FALSE}
eLog ~ 1 + (ot1 + ot2 + ot3) + l1_sum + ot:l1_sum +
    condition_sum + ot1:condition_sum + ot2:condition_sum + 
    use_z + ot1:use_z + ot2:use_z + l1_sum:condition_sum:use_z +
    ot1:l1_sum:condition_sum:use_z + ot2:l1_sum:condition_sum:use_z +
    ot3:l1_sum:condition_sum:use_z +
    (1 + condition_sum + ot1 + ot2 + ot3 | participant) +
    (1 + ot1 + ot2 + ot3 | target)
```

# Discussion

## Does L1 transfer affect English and Mandarin Chinese speakers' ability to make stress-tense suffix predictions in L2 Spanish? If so, how?

## Does L2 use affect English and Mandarin Chinese speakers' ability to make stress-tense suffix predictions in L2 Spanish? If so, how?

- English faster and more likely to predict than Chinese speakers because of similarity > No effect
- More use will contribute to faster and likelier prediction > Faster
  - Interaction with stress pattern/suffix

---

# Discussion

- No L1 cross-linguistic influence 
  - Proficiency levels, language experience <font size="-1">(Gosselke et al., 2018)</font></br>
  - Languages need to differ more?
  

---

# Discussion

- No L1 cross-linguistic influence 
  - Proficiency levels, language experience <font size="-1">(Gosselke et al., 2018)</font></br>
  - Languages need to differ more?
  </br> 
    </br> 
      </br> 
- L2 use contributed to faster prediction rate
  - Language experience in general facilitates speed of phonomorphological prediction <font size="-1">(Proficiency: Sagarra & Casillas, 2018; anticipatory experience: Lozano-Argüelles et al., 2020)</font>
  - Interplay with other factors
    - proficiency?
  - Still later than monolinguals <font size="-1">(e.g., Perdomo & Kaan, 2019)</font>

---

# Discussion

- No L1 cross-linguistic influence 
  - Proficiency levels, language experience <font size="-1">(Gosselke et al., 2018)</font></br>
  - Languages need to differ more?
  </br> 
    </br> 
      </br> 
- L2 use helpful
  - Language experience in general facilitates speed of phonomorphological prediction <font size="-1">(Proficiency: Sagarra & Casillas, 2018; anticipatory experience: Lozano-Argüelles et al., 2020)</font>
  - Interplay with other factors
    - proficiency?
  - Still later than monolinguals <font size="-1">(e.g., Perdomo & Kaan, 2019)</font>
  </br> 
    </br> 
      </br> 
- Oxytones predicted more but paroxytones faster (the more the use)
  - In general, less frequent option easier <font size="-1">(oxytones, Morales Font, 2013)</font>
  - Once suffix activated, faster rate because of more certainty
  
---

# Discussion

Findings support L2 usage-based models:
  - language experience in L2 processing and prediction
  - characteristics of input in terms of frequency, validity, reliability

---

# Conclusion

- L1 cross-linguistic influence may depend on proficiency
- L2 use helps only in rate of prediction
- Frequency of phonomorphological association matters
